Nvidia recently released patches for high-severity vulnerabilities found in various artificial intelligence (AI) and networking products. These products include Jetson devices, Mellanox OS, OnyX, Skyway, and MetroX. The vulnerabilities could potentially allow attackers to execute code, escalate privileges, deny service, disclose information, and tamper with data. Specifically, one vulnerability affects Jetson products used for robotics and AI applications, while others target the Mellanox OS switch operating system for data centers, the OnyX successor, the Skyway InfiniBand-to-Ethernet gateway, and the MetroX long-haul system.

Blacklist nouveau.2. Install build-essential, pkg-config and libglvnd-dev.3. Invoke init 3 (to go to runlevel 3 on Linux Mint & others).4. sudo sh NVIDIA-Linux-x86_64-550.107.02.run5. I can be pragmatic in many cases, use stuff which works - prefer FOSS when there are real alternatives.But nvidia ... They deliberately try to get a free pass in with their proprietary driver. The "open source" Linux kernel driver you get from them is essentially just a firmware loader ... Which tries to circumvent the limitations internal GPL export restricted functions have, inside that binary blob.And that, dear friends, is one of the reasons this driver can make your system end up in crashes ... When it tries to access restricted functions using an expected interface, where an internal kernel interface may have changed sufficiently with a kernel update to break unexpected users of it.Drivers doing the right thing, typically don't end up in this mess ... Because they use properly public exposed APIs which has a different guarantee to stability. So if that driver is a proper GPL licenced driver, it has access to all the GPL tagged functions in the kernel directly and doesn't need to do this wonky stuff.And that's why deserves to be completely ignored by users. They deliberately try to access kernel functionality in particularly restricted from their driver - because it's not a proper GPL driver.'s might not be equally good compared to what nvidia can do. But at least, there are real open sourced, GPL based drivers for them.

Goldman Sachs: AI Is Overhyped, Wildly Expensive, and Unreliable
ğŸ“ŒSummary:
Goldman Sachs, one of the largest investment banks in the world, published a research paper expressing doubts about the economic viability of generative AI. The paper notes that there is "little to show for" the huge spending on generative AI infrastructure and questions whether this spending will ever pay off in terms of AI benefits and returns. The paper suggests that AI optimism is driving large growth in stocks like Nvidia and other S&P 500 companies, but argues that the stock price gains are based on the assumption that generative AI will lead to higher productivity and efficiency. The paper also suggests that companies are acting like generative AI is going to change the world, but that the technology is currently deeply unreliable and may not change much of anything at all.

ğŸ¯Key Points:
- Goldman Sachs questions the economic viability of generative AI.
- The bank notes that there is "little to show for" the huge spending on generative AI infrastructure and wonders whether it will ever pay off.
- The paper is based on a series of interviews with Goldman Sachs economists and researchers, MIT professor Daron Acemoglu, and infrastructure experts.
- Goldman Sachs argues that AI optimism is driving large growth in stocks like Nvidia and other S&P 500 companies.
- The bank suggests that the stock price gains are based on the assumption that generative AI will lead to higher productivity and efficiency.
- The paper argues that generative AI is currently deeply unreliable and may not change much of anything at all.
- The bank expresses skepticism about both the cost of generative AI and its ultimate transformative potential.

I have a tip.If you're working in UE5 with an Nvidia RTX 4090 on a desktop PC game, turn off anti-aliasing, turn on hardware ray tracing, and use Hit Lighting for Reflections in Lumen (the latter likely eats a few clocks in really dense scenes - I haven't noticed). I also have Ray Traced Shadows on. That card needs no help. Let it do what it was designed to do. The alternatives are for lesser GPUs. The results are gorgeous. The editor is behaving itself. It's all good.

NVIDIA wykorzystuje zestaw Apple Vision Pro do rejestrowania zdalnych demonstracji i kontrolowania robotÃ³w humanoidalnych.Proces ten obejmuje uÅ¼ycie Vision Pro do nagrywania teleoperowanych demonstracji, ktÃ³re sÄ… nastÄ™pnie symulowane w NVIDIA Isaac Sim.Dane te sÄ… przetwarzane przez mikroserwis MimicGen NIM do generowania syntetycznych zbiorÃ³w danych.
Training foundation models for humanoid robots requires an incredible amount of data. One way of capturing human demonstration data is using teleoperation, but this is becoming an increasingly expensive and lengthy process.An NVIDIA AI- and Omniverse-enabled teleoperation reference workflow, , allows researchers and AI developers to generate massive amounts of synthetic motion and perception data from a minimal amount of remotely captured human demonstrations.First, developers use Apple Vision Pro to capture a small number of teleoperated demonstrations. Then, they simulate the recordings in NVIDIA Isaac Sim and use the MimicGen NIM microservice to generate synthetic datasets from the recordings.The developers train the  humanoid foundation model with real and synthetic data, enabling developers to save time and reduce costs. They then use the Robocasa NIM microservice in , a framework for robot learning, to generate experiences to retrain the robot model. Throughout the workflow, NVIDIA OSMO seamlessly assigns computing jobs to different resources, saving the developers weeks of administrative tasks.

Unfortunately :freecad: does not run on :wayland: (maybe itâ€™s an issue?). By using this issue can be circumvented.It of course comes with all the downsides of Xwayland, like lower performance, running less stable, etc.With this custom startup script at least the scaling on my 4K 28" screen is fixed (you might want to tinker with the QT_FONT_DPI value). Just place as file with 755 permissions in /usr/local/bin/freecad.
#!/bin/bash
QT_QPA_PLATFORM=xcb \
QT_AUTO_SCREEN_SCALE_FACTOR=0 \    
QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1 \    
QT_FONT_DPI=160 \    
QT_SCREEN_SCALE_FACTORS=1 \    
/usr/bin/freecad "$@"

Ubuntu 24.10 Plans to Enable Wayland for NVIDIA UsersUbuntu first switched to using Wayland as its default display server in 2017 before reverting the following year. It tried again in 2021 and has stuck with it since. But while Wayland is what most of login to after installing Ubuntu anyone doing so on a PC or laptop with a NVIDIA graphics card present are instead logged in to an Xorg/X11 session. This is because the NVIDIAâ€™s proprietary graphics drivers (which provide the best performance, access to all hardware capabilities, etc) havenâ€™t supported Wayland as well as they couldâ€™ve. Thankfully, things have changed. NVIDIA is now warming to Wayland :sys_more_orange:

How can one best take advantage of the beefy on newer MacBook Pros for doing machine learning? Are there options for traditional methods from as well as . Seems like most of the open source packages are aimed at /

Made this post a while back about (and related things) on compared to . TLDR; gaming performance has been fine, with some minor quirks (at least on ) such as performing better somehow without than with (which is fine by me) - the only "issue" had to do with / while also running a .

I did some further digging and honestly, I don't think there's much issue/performance hit with gaming while recording on , using NVIDIA . I haven't really done proper testing, but it honestly has been fine. My games hit 144FPS, or close at 1440p Max settings pretty easily w my 3080 Ti. I record them by simply adding a "Window Capture" scene and selecting the appropriate window, that's it. People recommended "obs-vkcapture" on my last post, and that's been nice too - with that plugin, you only need a single "Game Capture" scene on OBS, and add a launch param to the game's properties on . Once you launch the game, OBS will immediately be "hooked" to the game and ready to record. People mentioned that doing it this way should prolly be more performant/efficient, but from my limited testing, both ways seem fine.

One thing I forgot to mention though was . Voicemeeter's a really freaking neat audio tool on Windows that allowed you to essentially have a virtual audio interface. It does plenty of things, but what I and most people use it for is to split several application audio into separate audio tracks i.e. is on one audio track, on another, on another, and so on. This was essential as it allowed me to record my games while being on a Discord call, or have playing and not have any audio but the game's to be included in the recording using OBS.

I did a quick search and found a plugin called "obs-pipewire-audio-capture" that solved this need. If your distro is already using for audio (which I think most/all distro do for the past few years), enabling this plugin is as easy as installing the plugin by downloading it from their repo and adding it to OBS's plugins folder. After a restart, you can now add multiple audio tracks as scenes to OBS for each application i.e. Spotify, Discord, Games, etc. and enable/disable any of these tracks accordingly for your recording.

All in all, no issues at all recording while gaming/anything. My only issue now has to do with streaming games to friends while gaming i.e. through Discord. Discord does not yet support this (with audio) on Linux, but there's a custom Discord client that's able to do this called "discord-screenaudio" though with a sizeable performance hit if you're going to be streaming anything intensive such as games - anything else (that isn't intensive) like , , etc. has been (mostly) perfectly fine.

Discord surprised us last year by claiming/maintaining the Discord on , PLEASE surprise us again by giving us STREAMING WITH AUDIO.

I always feared that the AI data center boom was likely going to make the looming climate catastrophe inevitable, but there was something about seeing it all presented on a platter with a smile and an excited presentation that struck me as more than just tone-deaf. It was damn near revolting.
A sobering take on and the future it envisions. I find it more surreal than revolting--how do people not see that this future being conjured is not possible for us?--but yes, the tech sector has jumped the shark. The possible futures tech companies are evoking are revolting to a lot of people, not enticing or exciting.

Right, as far as I know the GPU in a hybrid laptop cannot be turned off. It always draws some amount of power, on or on Windows. Typically, output defaults to the Intel, with the Nvidia used when the user tells an app to use it. Anyone else getting increasingly annoyed at the  targeted  from the likes of  still being referred to as "GPUs" ?Sure, the tech has its roots in that of actual Graphical Processing Units that us  love, but even if the H100 has some amount of FP64 and FP32 compute it has *far* more FP16, FP8 and INT8, and the last time I checked these AI-oriented 'GPU's **don't even have any way to get a video signal out**.Sure, you could use one to calculate something then export and display via other means, but their core use case *isn't for graphics any more*.I guess I'm favour of the newer  term.I might just be sore because all this AI hype is taking NVIDIA' (and probably AMD's too) attention away from the gaming market and we could well suffer for it.

I'm not a CUDA programmer, but that's not the point of the talk. It gives a clear mental model of what's important for GPUs running effectively. Memory transfer rates are more important than the GPU core speed. The transfer rates are often 10x slower than the processors themselves - and accessing memory rows badly also give a 10x wasted effort. 100x loss on the same program. We're going to see "Grace Hopper"-like GPU shared memory dominate.

Speaking of the landscape on , I think performance-wise it's certainly been comparable between Linux and . I definitely have not noticed any difference between the two, not to say there isn't any. Compatibility wise, most games should work out of the box on , especially if the game does not use any anti cheat software that specifically prohibits from working on Linux. Pretty much all games I'm interested in playing don't have this issue.

The ONLY difference I notice between when I was still on Windows, and now that I've primarily and exclusively been using Linux for over a year for all things including gaming, is the streaming/recording experience while gaming. I've always used an GPU since it's always offered not just the most performant but more importantly to me, the most efficient graphics card. One nice thing about NVIDIA cards is the NVENC encoder, which from what I've been keeping tabs on, 's implementation/equivalent to it has still not matched/surpassed NVENC.

Back when NVENC 1.0 came out, my gaming experience (when I was still on Windows) changed entirely as it allowed me to game AND stream/record my gameplay on the same PC with barely any performance cost. When they upgraded to NVENC 2.0, that performance cost continues to go down drastically, and I have never gamed without recording or streaming my gameplay to my partner/friends via .

On Linux, for one, Discord does not yet natively support streaming an application with audio (which renders it pointless). I work around this by using a custom Discord client instead, Discord-screenaudio which is available as a . For recording purposes, I still use . So, the only difference so far in gaming on Windows and on Linux, is that on Linux, I absolutely cannot game while also recording or streaming on the same PC. It's fine if I delegate the recording/streaming to another PC via a capture card, but I don't do that as that'd be too costly. There's NVENC support too on OBS on Linux, but for whatever reason, while recording and gaming simultaneously on the same device on Windows gave me pretty much no performance hit, it butchers my performance significantly if I do the same on Linux.

I feel like this is one of the few things that could be improved, gaming-wise on Linux. If you're not a data hoarder and you live life dangerously without the need to document/record absolutely everything you do including gaming, you're fine gaming on either platform lol. On Linux, at least on NVIDIA GPU, you will certainly need a secondary PC to do your streaming/recording while you're gaming.

Lilbits: Fedora 41 for Apple Silicon, NVIDIAâ€™s new $249 AI dev kit, and Android 16 DP2NVIDIAâ€™s latest Jetson platform for AI development is more powerful than its predecessor, but costs half as much. Radxa has launched a new motherboard for folks that want a powerful ARM-based processor in a mini ITX form-factor. Thereâ€™s a new build of Fedora available for Macs with Apple Silicon. And Google has released another developer preview of the next version of Android.Hereâ€™s a roundup of recent tech news from around the web.NVIDIA Jetson Orin Nano Super Developer KitThe  is a $249 dev kit (module + carrier board) with up to 67 TOPS AI performance. Itâ€™s half the prices of the , while offering 70% more AI performance and 50% more memory bandwidth. This 170 x 170mm (6.7â€³ x 6.7â€³) board features a Qualcomm 8cs Gen 3 processor four 2.8 GHz ARM Cortex-A720 CPU cores, four more at 2.4 GHz, and four 1.8GHz Cortex-A520 cores. The also has Immortalis-G720 graphics and a 30 TOPS AI accelerator, up to 64GB of RAM, two 5 Gb Ethernet ports, a PCIe 4.0 x4 connector for storage, a PCIe x16 slot, and an M.2 E-Key for a wireless card, among other things. The board is available from or for about $200 and up. Android 16 Developer Preview 2 is now available, with performance and battery life improvements as well as new developer APIs. Itâ€™s available for Google Pixel 6 and later devices.Googleâ€™s recent smartphones ship with Tensor processors designed in-house by Google, but they use modems designed by Samsung. It looks like next yearâ€™s Pixel 10 could ship with a MediaTek T900 modem instead.The latest release brings Fedora 41 to Macs with Apple Silicon. It includes support for x86-64 emulation and Vulkan 1.4 graphics, making it possible to play some games on Apple Silicon. "The Supreme Court will soon weigh two cases that could potentially make it harder for misled investors to sue Big Tech companies after major scandals.One case involves one of the largest tech scandals of all time, the Facebook-Cambridge Analytica data breach. In 2019, Facebook agreed to pay "more than $5 billion in civil penalties to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it had misled its users and investors over the privacy and security of user data on its platform," a Supreme Court filing said.The other case involves an allegation that Nvidia intentionally hid how much of its 2017â€“2018 GPU demand was due to a volatile cryptocurrency boom and not Nvidia's core gaming businessâ€”allegedly misleading investors ahead of a crypto crash. After the bust, Nvidia suddenly had to slash half a billion dollars from its earnings projection, and market experts later estimated that the firm had understated its crypto-related revenue by more than a billion. In 2022, Nvidia paid a $5.5 million SEC penalty over the inadequate disclosures that one SEC chief said "deprived investors of critical information to evaluate the companyâ€™s business in a key market."Investors, however, have not yet settled their own legal challenges. In both cases, investors suing convinced the 9th Circuit that the companies were guilty of misleading investors. But now, the tech companies have appealed to the Supreme Court, hoping to reverse those rulings."

Before bed, I want to tell a quick troubleshooting story:I switched to Wayland!
But DCS: World has a weird frame flickering issue.
I try Proton, doesn't help.
I try different Wine version, doesn't help.
I try messing with DXVK, doesn't help.
It's an NVIDIA driver issue related to XWayland.
I admit defeat and go back to X11.
But: Wine can be run in native Wayland mode!
I find out how to run Wine without XWayland.
It works flawlessly and more performant than ever before!And now I'm going to bed happy.

Ways to manage unfree software under .
Such as beloved and # Leaves the door wide open
```nix
config.allowUnfree = true;
```# More restrictive but must write every single package
```nix
config.allowUnfreePredicate = pkg: builtins.elem (lib.getName pkg) [
"nvida_pkg"
"nvidia_other_stuff
];
```# Less verbose thx to regex ğŸ¤—
```nix
allow-unfree = [ "nvidia-.*" "cuda.*" ];
```

If you're considering Arch Linux as your primary distro but are afraid of instabilities, this is a good example of the kind of issues you would run into from time to time.I upgraded my system and was left with a black screen. Oh no! But both the KDE and Arch Linux wiki had instructions that the kernel parameter `nvidia_drm.modeset=1` was required for Plasma on Wayland.One reboot later, everything worked fine. This is why I recommend Arch to anyone who is not afraid to get their hands dirty. The documentation is top notch. You will run into problems, but you will be able to resolve them fairly quickly. If another distro forgets this kernel parameter, you're out of luck.

130 has made it to , and so far - reenabling hardware acceleration does not crash the browser while in use so I reckon this bug with on has been fixed <3 Having stuck without HW acceleration for months, while usable, having it back again makes the browser feels insanely silky smooth - especially when doing stuffs such as typing.

On the other hand though, Firefox is still so fucking annoying to use due to the big behavioural change. Previously with my Firefox History settings - pinned tabs remain pinned, user credential forms gets autofilled or rather suggested to be autofilled, and my history (and only history, not cookies etc.) gets cleared.

Since Firefox 129 or so, none of that is true except the last bit. It makes using it feels like a big fucking chore. Is there even a solution to this? My expectation is literally just, behave the exact same as you would with 90% of the users sticking with defaults, 'cept, clear my history when the session ends. That's it, why is it seemingly so hard to achieve on Firefox (esp when it wasn't)?

Announcements from Qlik Connect | Gestalt IT Rundown: June 5, 2024At Qlik Connect in Orlando, significant announcements affecting the industry were examined. Key highlights included the integration of Talend Cloud to enhance data pipeline capabilities and the introduction of Qlik Answers, an AI-powered knowledge assistant tailored to enterprise data. The partnership with the United Nations to support climate change initiatives by leveraging data analytics was also discussed. Additionally, Qlik announced the formation of an AI Council composed of experts to guide their AI strategy. The discussions on data quality and seamless integration were particularly impressive and insightful. This and more on The Rundown. Thanks to Gina Rosenthal for cohosting.  |  |  |  |  |  â€“ Ticketmaster Hacked in Data Breach Live Nation, parent company of Ticketmaster, filed a data breach with federal employees for an event that occured on May 20. A bad actor was selling their customersâ€™ data on the dark web, They attributed the breach to a â€œthird party cloud database, which turn out to be Snowflake. During the investigation, one of the credentials belonged to a Snowflake employee. Read More: â€“ NVIDIA Reveals Next-Gen AI Chips â€œRubinâ€ Most major tech companies are at Computex in Taiwan this week, and weâ€™re seeing a flood of announcements. The industry is buzzing following Jensen Huangâ€™s announcement of the next-generation Rubin GPU platform and associated Vera Arm CPUs. These will replace Grace, Hopper, and Grace Hopper as Nvidiaâ€™s scalable AI platform in 2026 and beyond. Itâ€™s excellent to see Nvidia honor another woman in science with their platform names, in this case American astronomer Vera Rubin who passed away in 2016.Read More: â€“ Google Cloud Customer Account Wiped UniSuper is an Australian pension fund manager. Google confirmed this was an unprecedented, one of a kind outage. Read More: â€“ Infinidat Announces G4 Storage Platform Infinidat just introduced their biggest upgrade to date, enhancing their Infinibox enterprise storage platform with higher performance, cyber resilience, and hybrid multi-cloud offering in Azure and AWS. Lots of enterprise hardware companies have updated their offerings with the latest Intel Xeon CPUs, but Infinidat is headed in a different direction, using the latest AMD Epyc processors. Infinidat also claims to be the first high-end storage company to allow customers to updgrade just the controller, keeping their existing media.Read More: â€“ Ciscoâ€™s AI Innovations and Investments At Cisco Live 2024, Cisco unveiled a series of AI-powered innovations aimed at enhancing digital resilience by integrating advanced networking, security, and observability capabilities. Cisco also introduced a $1 billion Global AI Investment Fund to drive industry innovation and customer readiness.Since Tom Hollingsworth is attending Cisco Live for The Futurum Group, letâ€™s check in with him on these announcements.Read More: â€“ Announcements from Qlik ConnectAt Qlik Connect in Orlando, significant announcements affecting the industry were examined. I remember seeing my brothers' PCs just stopped getting upgraded, including their GPUs. My eldest brother's PC stopped "growing" with an ~500 (or 700) series. My second brother's PC stopped at an NVIDIA GTX 1070.

Mine was upgraded several times from a GTX 1050 Ti, to GTX 1070 Ti, to an 2070 Super, and lastly to an RTX 3080 Ti ~2 years ago using money I got from a job I did funded by the EU lol (otherwise... I would never have gotten an XX80 series honestly).

Seeing my brothers' PCs and the sad state they're in, I swore I'd not "grow old" and stop upgrading my PC hardware every couple of years. Now, I fully understand them not because of the rising commitments of them having families of their own etc. but just... this is enough lol and I suspect it will be enough for ~6-10 years at least. No offense, but my younger self would think I sound boomer as hell rn saying what I just said.

Now it seems most machine learning coding is in Python with lots of libraries. What is a library? We know it when openGL was outsourced from CPU to GPU to calculate graphic simulation. OpenGL was the standard library every game was coded with, but needed specific GPU for it to calculate fast. For every new game you needed a new better graphic card so that the blowing up calculating with bottle necks could be calculated faster. Nvidia has similar libraries for machine learning now specifically working on their GPU and is called CUDA. Most open source Python engineers work with it, but is not needed and makes machine learning depending on Nvidia as it was with openGL games. For scientific projects there are lot of other graphic simulation libraries in machine learning also to use full capacity of the multiple matrix working parallel in Tensor cores with Tensor flow with much higher bit rate to calculate parallel with multiple threads.

Here's the AMD w/ CUDA support/library/api/shim/translation/thing that came up the other day:> ZLUDA is a drop-in replacement for CUDA on non-NVIDIA GPU. ZLUDA allows to run unmodified CUDA applications using non-NVIDIA GPUs with near-native performance.-

La industria de los podria entrar en crisis

Los grandes jugadores como , , , tienen un problema muy gordo ad portas... hasta hace 5 aÃ±os vendian hasta 50% de sus chips a clientes chinos y la declaracion de que hizo Trump a , fue un duro golpe para todas

Tal fue la crisis, que todas se apuraron en tiempo record a exportar todo lo que consiguieron al mercado asiatico. Tambien desarrollaron en pocas semanas versiones especificas bajo las nuevas condiciones para ese mercado

Y algunos rumores hablan de que hicieron la vista gorda a muchas de las formas en que terceras empresas se comenzaron a saltar estas prohibiciones para seguir suministrando ya fuera via integrados en otros dispositivos o simplemente bajo otra denominacion

Pero el aumento de los precios, la interrupcion de las cadenas de suministro, y la continua diatriba mantenida por el gobierno usamericano estan afectando especialmente a las tecnologicas de terceros paises, pues domesticamente esta oxigenando con sendos subsidios y programas de ayuda, que en la practica han tenido como consecuencia una ralentizacion por 'falta de competencia' del desarrollo en este campo

Asi empresas de terceros paises como , , , , se encuentran en el fuego cruzado, bajo mucha presion

Por su parte, China acelero a fondo y las cientos de empresas del sector estan recibiendo un schock de cortizona, es decir, no extraÃ±a que semanalmente laboratorios tecnologicos compartan sus desarrollos e inmediatamente la industria sea invitada a probarlas y adoptarlas, bajo la promesa de jugosos premios y favores publicos... lo que mantiene la motivacion al borde de un ataque de extasis

A la vez el Gobierno esta desinsentivando la adquisicion de tecnologias extranjeras, ya sea a traves de listas negras (ya le tomo el gustito a lo que viene haciendo por su parte ) o haciendo llamamientos publicos para buscar otros caminos

Las consecuencias ya se sienten. Nvidia en tiempo record desarrollo varias lineas de chips exclusivamente para sus clientes chinos y su filial en el pais asiatico lo ha tenido muy movido dando explicaciones a los chinos para dar garantias de calidad... aun asi ya ha perdido mas del 50% de ese mercado y se espera que antes de que finalice la decada sea devorada en su totalidad por las soluciones locales

La crisis esta ad portas. ASML perdio en un solo dia mas de 15% de capitalizacion a causa de los malos resultados en China y esta desesperada por la ayuda de su pais Holanda y conseguir la liberacion de las sanciones de para volver a vender con normalidad en el gigante mercado asiatico... pero probablemente para cuado usamerica se lo permita ya sea demasiado tarde, si es que ya no lo es

A pesar de que todos los ingenieros occidentales niegan de que la industria china este a los mismos niveles de la competencia, reconocen que sus avances a dia de hoy 'le serian imposible, impensable para cualquier otro pais normal bajo el asedio que le impuso' USA

A este ritmo, es seguro que China llegue al nivel de occidente en cuestion de muchisimo menos de lo que se habia pronosticado al comienzo

Recordemos que la inversion en estos campos implica un esfuerzo titanico para cualquier economia y el desgaste puede llevar aparejado otros problemas... pero la prensa occidental evita hablar de este aspecto, pues quien sale muy mal parado es claramente la mafia encabezada por EEUU, con un decifit creciendo aceleradamente

Â¿Como puede ser que una economia con caracteristicas de subdesarrollo logre mantener tales niveles de inversion, adelantar en su calidad, sin perjuducar sus objetivos economicos?

China lo esta consiguiendo y USA se desespera

Nvidia isn't an AI company. They're a chipmaker whose products (designed originally for niche gamers) happened to be really good at a very specific kind of math that current LLMs use heavily. This is the tech equivalent of finding oil in your backyard.And now, shocker, it turns out that future models may not even use matrix multiplication.It's crazy that a niche business got lucky twice with massive off-label use of their gaming chips (crypto and now LLMs). Certainly, LLMs are actually useful products, but the idea that their usefulness should make Nvidia the most valuable company IN THE WORLD is absolutely insane, especially considering that they're being valued above companies like Microsoft that are actually building the tools themselves (in this case, I'm just assuming that everyone understands that OpenAI is functionally a division of Microsoft).

Holy shit, just announced a built-into recording feature on PCs and also on - we've been asking for this and they've delivered (very quickly, in Valve's books)!!!

It's pretty feature packed too - sporting a timeline which shows highlights of in-game events happening including Steam achievements and when you take a screenshot, a Replay feature, you could also create short Clips from the raw recording, and a Save/Share menu to easily export or share your clips between devices or to friends in Chat.

The recording is done automatically in the background when you start a game based on the predefined quality and storage limit you've set (it'll overwrite old recordings as you go past the limit), or you can also record on demand. This new Game Recording feature will work with any game that does not disable the Steam Overlay, and has minimal CPU usage as it supports hardware acceleration with / GPUs. Interesting to see how it fares on the Steam Deck's APU though.

That's 2 super interesting features now currently cooking in Steam Beta, including the (revamped) announced some months ago. I'm not a Beta kind of person when it comes to Steam (or just in general), but I'm looking forward to when these land on Stable.

Honestly, besides all the basic economic reasons that this cannot last, the application area is one math theorem away from imploding.

All it'd take is one clever math result demonstrating you don't need absolutely gigantic neural networks trained on mind-bogglingly-huge datasets to achieve the AI goals of most companies, and NVIDIA's hardware dominance evaporates. Why would you spend thousands or tens of thousands of dollars on a GPU that uses 300 Watts of power when you could achieve the same thing with an ASIC or FPGA that uses 3 Watts? This is already true for many applications, but apparently it hasn't been widely realized yet. It'll be hard to ignore if/when it becomes true for the vast majority of applications. Which it could.

Before the GPU became a household name, add-in solutions were referred to as 3D game and video accelerators which included the likes of the Riva TNT or the 3dfx Voodoo3. With the launch of the 256, the entire industry changed forever.

If you lived in Sudan, over 40 years.
In Somalia, over 50 years.
Afghanistan, over a century.All obviously "rather reasonable" figures as well.

Ugh. Currently dealing with a geriatric 15yo MacBook Pro 5,3, cuz havenâ€™t budgeted to upgrade. Itâ€™s limped along fine with various DEs on :arch: and Linux Mint Debian edition. But lately itâ€™s havingâ€¦ bus problems? Nouveau intermittently complains (when in TTY before or after DE), and the trackpad cursor gets jerky & refuses taps. On any distro (Arch, Fedora, EndeavourOS, LMDE), either in Gnome (which Iâ€™m impressed it can run, even in Wayland; but screen glitches at buttons & off to the side of windows quickly catch up to it) or in Cinnamon (X11 or Wayland, though I donâ€™t do the latter much, as thatâ€™s still experimental); these jerky cursor & tap-refusing issues even show up in super-light DE/WMs like XFCE (X11) and Sway (Wayland)! Iâ€™ve tried KDE, and besides just not liking ALL the superfluous configurability that makes it REALLY easy to bork your interface, apps with high refresh of text data (like System Monitor) just show blue blocks where the text should be, and SDDM often shows unflushed last-session screen redraw data. Itâ€™s really finicky about which screen youâ€™re using, even on a one-screen laptopâ€¦ yeah, no KDE for me (as a daily driver; Iâ€™ll check it out from time to time in a VM, cuz I DO like that the panel now floats by default in 6. Thatâ€™s it; thatâ€™s all I like.)
Anyway, back to these jerky cursor/tap-rejecting/eventual hang issues. Occasionally, the issues are concurrent with plugging in a USB stick (NVIDIA did the USB hardware at least on this model, if not the whole bus interface?), but occasionally they just happen after a while of being on (so heat? Too many processes for two CPU cores and/or a Nouveau-driven old GPU to handle? Some random bit of data getting stuck in the onboard/external busâ€™s craw?).
Iâ€™ve considered repasting the CPU (T9900) & the GPU (9400M/9600M GT) cuz they run a little hot (high 60s at idle, never more than 100Â°C when chugginâ€™, but close to that 105Â°C TjMax. Iâ€™m just not sure I want to perform that surgery that involves A LOT of 15yo ribbon cables & flipping the mobo over (at least it WAS accessible back in the day, but Apple has never REALLY done repairability any favors). Iâ€™ve done it once before, 3~4 years ago, but just not looking forward to the very real prospect of killing my only laptop without a replacement, especially when the damage may already have been done to the GPU and/or bus chips.
Iâ€™ve been looking at the AMD Framework 13â€ and am very impressed. Would likely put :arch: on it & in addition to daily driving while away from my perfectly usable but stuck-in-the-home-office desktop, I might even do some light gaming on it that Iâ€™ve never been able to do with the current Blast from the Past lappy. But again, that would be at least several months of saving up/taking extra work that Iâ€™m not sure this lappy will survive.
Weâ€™ll see. Itâ€™s a miracle* itâ€™s survived this long. I wiped macOS off of this old guy probably 3~4 years ago too, when the newest macOS that Apple would support (El Capitan) would no longer install modern Internet security (like WireGuard) via either brew or MacPorts (because it wouldnâ€™t run the latest version of either); and Legacy OpenCore Patcher would work to get it up to the â€œlatest & [questionably] greatestâ€ macOSâ€¦ but the fans would sound like a jumbo jet taking off the ENTIRE time it ran, with all the processes it was trying to push through two cores, to make silly visual effects or iCloud data harvesting work. So from then on, it was Linux all the way. My fans & temps have been thanking me ever since!
Anyway, after this latest round of â€œLetâ€™s see if itâ€™s hopefully software & if thereâ€™s another distro/DE I like better that minimizes the impact of this happening,â€ Iâ€™m going back to LMDE/Cinnamon/X11 for now. Iâ€™m fine with, and my muscle memory specific to the laptop has grown to Cinnamon, but I really like Gnome (as on my desktop rig). On the lappy though, the visual glitches & instability of getting back into a graphical session after these issues REALLY bug me.
*Not a Voyager-1-team-working-around-a-fried-FDS-to-send-back-usable-data miracleâ€¦ by which I mean both a LOT of hard engineering work & and lot of luck. But a minor miracle in comparison, nonetheless.

I know modern GPU on runs pretty much perfectly fine - people like to say you gotta go (on Linux) but I've seen and heard enough to know that AMD on Linux isn't as pretty as people like to boast, in fact I keep seeing creators/professionals preferring or outright needing an NVIDIA GPU on Linux for their tasks cos they weren't supported or preferable to be done on AMD.

For me personally, for as long as AMD GPUs stay the way they are, I'll never buy em - I buy their CPUs cos I think they're (+ the platform as a whole i.e. mobo/chipset) the best for me, but not their GPUs. They're a lot more expensive vs NVIDIA GPUs where I am, but the cost isn't the problem but rather it's obviously a more inferior product in every way. I'm willing and have paid a fair fortune for products that are really good on Linux but AMD GPUs with their weaker performance (acceptable) and worse efficiency (deal-breaker) ain't it.

OK that being said - my actual purpose of this post (fucking hell my brain runs off on a tangent daily), I wonder how usable/stable is Linux on ~older NVIDIA GPUs (like Pascal GTX10 series and older)? My RTX 3080 Ti runs like a dream, and it's true for my Turing cards too (RTX 20/GTX 16 series), but I'm planning to install on my sister's PC running a GTX 1050 Ti and I'm curious if 6 with would be as good/stable as it is on my other computers.

Okta has since fixed the issue by updating its cryptographic algorithm and advises affected customers to review access logs from the past three months.Read More: â€“ Nuclear Amazon Datacenters Denied over Safety Concerns Back on Oct 2, Tom and I talked about nuclear power for AI datacenters. Amazonâ€™s plans to power new U.S. datacenters with nuclear energy faced a setback after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission rejected an agreement allowing it to draw additional power from the Susquehanna nuclear plant, citing potential impacts on grid reliability and consumer costs. Despite FERC Chairman Willie L. Phillips advocating for approval, FERC ruled that the proposal lacked sufficient support, raising concerns over preferential treatment and the potential effects of similar arrangements on the grid in future cases.Read More: Read More: â€“ Microsoft Recalls Recall. Again. Microsoft has once again delayed the release of its new AI Recall feature for Copilot Plus PCs, pushing the preview for Windows Insiders to December. Recall, which was originally slated for an October release, has been plagued by concerns about its security and privacy implications. The delays stem from Microsoftâ€™s efforts to address these concerns by making Recall an opt-in feature that can be fully uninstalled. Microsoft has been working to fix bugs in how the feature appears and is controlled in Windows 11. The company remains committed to delivering a secure and trusted experience with Recall.Read More: â€“ Cloudera Launches Private Link Cloudera recently launched the Cloudera Private Link Network, a service designed to provide secure, internet-free connectivity across multi-cloud environments. This network allows data to travel securely between customer workloads and Clouderaâ€™s Control Plane without traversing the public internet, addressing privacy and regulatory concerns for industries like finance, healthcare, and pharmaceuticals. By using services like AWS PrivateLink and Azure Private Link, the Private Link Network enables consistent security across cloud providers, reducing the complexities of cross-cloud setups and lowering total costs by simplifying network management. This development marks Clouderaâ€™s effort to support enterprises with strict data protection needs in leveraging multi-cloud environments efficiently. For more on this, letâ€™s turn to our colleague Mitch Ashley.Read More: â€“ Google Cloud gets Multi-Factor Authentication In response to rising cyber threats and high-profile data breaches, Google has announced that it will require all Google Cloud users to enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) by 2025. Starting this month, users will receive reminders to implement MFA, with mandatory enforcement beginning in the new year. This policy shift, aimed at protecting against unauthorized access through stolen credentials, aligns Google with other cloud giants like AWS and Microsoft, which have also moved to enforce MFA. Google says this requirement addresses the heightened security risks in enterprise cloud environments, where sensitive data remains a prime target for cyberattacks.Read More: â€“ Supermicro Faces Financial Woes as NVIDIA Seeks New Suppliers Needham suspended its buy rating for Super Micro Computer (SMCI) after Ernst & Young resigned as auditor, citing governance issues and concerns about financial transparency amid an ongoing DOJ investigation and Hindenburg Researchâ€™s allegations of accounting manipulation. So, the good news is, we're in a really good place for desktop use for daily driving. You can pick just about any major distro/flavor, and have a pretty great daily driving experience for everyday tasks. I think the first step would be to identify what your must-have use cases are in Windows, outside of normal, day to day browsers/email apps/etc. i.e. do you like to game? Do any photography? Make music? etc.
Any graphics cards in the mix?Those more specific uses/hardware can help steer you towards a distro flavor that might be tailor-made for a specifically good fit for the things you enjoy. Also, for beginners, all the distro choices can feel overwhelming, and everyone has strong opinions. Much of that can be greatly simplified by restricting yourself to the broad families that are out there. For most beginners, I'd recommend thinking of it like this:
- a family distro (the biggest/oldest tree, and includes , , , etc.)
- a Fedora / family distro
- an family distroEverything else you see is just "flavoring" on one of those families. There are other families, but I don't think you need to care about them right now.Good visualization here: I'd rather you find a cool distro that you like, and enjoy the experience, without any of the decision/distro paralysis.I personally run a family distro, but I've also used Debian distros plenty, and they are also great.

Folks that have dealt with drivers will be like "duh" but there's A LOT of different misinfo around the web about this issue.Putting this in modprobe.d* or kernel command-line fixed it:option nvidia-drm modeset=1I use nVidia's open drivers, and I wasn't aware I STILL had to add this to the module's settings. And you need this specifically so nVidia's drivers can fully initialize on boot with the other GPU (and that explanation I had to find in a very specific search term and was not on the Arch Wiki).Specifically on my laptop, the APU is the main GPU, and the nVidia card the secondary one. However the outputs are by default wired to the nVidia card, so the AMD APU can't output to the HDMI port. There is a way to change that over, had my BIOS been unlocked. :blobPikaGlare:* Remember to recreate your initramfs when you change stuff in modprobe.d.

advice

If you are a beginner or not really an expert in Linuxâ€¦ do yourself a favor and inform yourself if your hardware is able to run Linux without problems.

That excluded anything with a graphics cards. Because they use proprietary non open source drivers. Why is that a problem? The most generic answer is: Linux Kernel developers don't care for what Nvidia does. They rely on Nvidia using well documented kernel APIs (and not deprecated ones that may work Today but not Tomorrow) for their driver in a correct way. It's known that Nvidia on the other hand doesn't care. For economic reasons (driver architecture overhauls are costly) and for arrogant reasons (look at our market share, Kernel developers â€“ you have to be compatible to our undocumented code, not the other way around).
If you ever wondered why Linus showed them the middle finger openly (at a Debian con, no less â€“ if I remember right), that's why.

It's almost guaranteed: When using a Nvidia card on a Linux distro that is not super conservative like Redhat you'll run into problems sooner or later you won't be able to solve easily without being a Linux expert.

Please think about my words when planning your next hardware shopping. I'm not against Nvidia hardware - it's great hardware. I just inform you that you ask for trouble when using it in a fairly modern Linux distro, and that is, because their drivers don't play well in the Eco system. And the only one who can change that, is Nvidia by themselves. There are no signs since decades, that they are willing to do so.

So what would I do when booting after an update and have no monitor image?

Change to a TTY and do a kernel downgrade. It's not much more in most cases, but apparently that is called expert level ;). --> You too can become an Linux expert!

Alright, after reinstalling NixOS for the second time on this machine, I have to say it's working flawlessly now! I readjusted my flake.nix, by rereading the nix wiki and seeing some forum posts, and everything works.
My main complaint was that my dGPU wasn't being recognized, and indeed it wasn't, but that was because I wasn't telling the OS to enable the xserver drivers to being with. By default, the programs will run on the iGPU, which is great for most tasks. That being said, if I need to use the dGPU for games or other intensive graphical workflows, I just need to type nvidia-offload <name of the program> in the terminal. It works for wine games as well! I can probably streamline the process by doing a script file for each game, and making it just a single step to start playing.
The only gripe I have right now, and honestly it's just a nitpick at this point, is that I have to either unplug or shutdown my secondary monitor before suspending my laptop, because otherwise it won't do so. I tested overnight to see if it would crash or something during the suspension, but in the morning it woke up absolutely fine! :)

: "And thereâ€™s another reason to be wary of a hyper-concentrated chip market: AI regulation, be it the EUâ€™s AI Act or the White House executive order on AI, is emerging slowly, putting Nvidia â€“ which gets to decide who gets chips for what â€“ in a quasi-regulatory role. Thatâ€™s not the way things should work; regulatory policy is a public function, and a for-profit company should not be allowed, through its sheer size, to fill the vacuum. But Nvidia likes it this way, and has stepped up lobbying to try to maintain its de facto control of global AI.Nvidiaâ€™s dramatic rise has taken many by surprise. But while it may be big techâ€™s â€œnew kid on the blockâ€, that doesnâ€™t mean it should get a free pass from regulators to abuse its monopoly power. By engaging in practices that lock in customers and keep out competitors, Nvidia is trying to rig the AI market in a way that furthers its interests while undermining the public interest. Competition authorities around the world were too slow to stop todayâ€™s tech giants from dominating Web 2.0. They canâ€™t afford to repeat the same mistake with Nvidia and AI."

StarCoder2 is a family of code generation models (3B, 7B, and 15B), trained on 600+ programming languages from  and some natural language text such as Wikipedia, Arxiv, and GitHub issues. The models use Grouped Query Attention, a context window of 16,384 tokens, with sliding window attention of 4,096 tokens. The 3B & 7B models were trained on 3+ trillion tokens, while the 15B was trained on 4+ trillion tokens. For more details check out the .

StarCoder2 is a family of open LLMs for code and comes in 3 different sizes with 3B, 7B and 15B parameters. The flagship StarCoder2-15B model is trained on over 4 trillion tokens and 600+ programming languages from The Stack v2. All models use Grouped Query Attention, a context window of 16,384 tokens with a sliding window attention of 4,096 tokens, and were trained using the Fill-in-the-Middle objective.StarCoder2 offers three model sizes: a 3 billion-parameter model trained by ServiceNow, a 7 billion-parameter model trained by Hugging Face, and a 15 billion-parameter model trained by NVIDIA using NVIDIA NeMo on NVIDIA accelerated infrastructure:

Commvault Shiftâ€™s Cyber Resilience for the AI Era | The Gestalt IT Rundown: October 16, 2024At Commvault SHIFT 2024, The Futurum Groupâ€™s Daniel Newman and Patrick Moorhead sat with CEO Sanjay Mirchandani, who discussed Commvaultâ€™s strategic pivot towards a cloud-first approach in cyber resilience. This shift involves key acquisitions, such as Appranix and Clumio, and new partnerships with AWS and Google, aimed at enhancing cloud data protection and recovery. Mirchandani also introduced the concept of â€œContinuous Business,â€ highlighting its distinction from traditional business continuity by emphasizing ongoing readiness and adaptability in a dynamic digital landscape. |  |  |  |  |  â€“ Chip Boom Continues with Record-Breaking Demand Global semiconductor sales jumped 20.6% year-on-year in August 2024, reaching $53.1 billion, with the Americas leading the growth at 43.9%, driven by AI, cloud computing, and automotive demand. Despite the strong recovery, supply chain disruptions and ongoing US-China geopolitical tensions pose significant risks to the industry. While export controls and national security concerns remain, the sector is expected to continue rebounding due to persistent demand across multiple sectors.Read More: â€“ Accenture Pushes Agentic AI Built on NVIDIA Accenture is positioning itself at the forefront of the emerging agentic AI wave by expanding its partnership with Nvidia to leverage advanced AI capabilities within its operations. The company is launching the Accenture Nvidia Business Group, which will employ an â€œarmy of agentsâ€ to tackle complex workflows, enhance efficiency, and deliver customized solutions for clients. While agentic AI presents significant opportunities for innovation, Accenture acknowledges the challenges of data security, ethical considerations, and the necessity for human oversight as these systems become increasingly autonomous.Read More: â€“ AMD AI Chips to Challenge NVIDIA AMD announced the release of its MI325X AI accelerator in 2025, followed by the MI350 series, which will feature 256GB of memory and 6TBps throughput, surpassing NVIDIAâ€™s H200 series. Additionally, the company introduced the AMD Pensando Pollara 400 Ethernet accelerator and a new 5th Gen EPYC processor that improves performance by up to 17%, while CEO Dr. Lisa Su stressed the importance of leveraging open-source software and building an ecosystem around the ROCm stack to compete effectively in the market. For more on this story, letâ€™s bring in Techstrong.aiâ€™s Mike Vizard to discuss what this means.Read More: â€“ Geopoliticsâ€™ Impact on Digital Infrastructure In his latest column on Every.to, Gareth Edwards explores the British governmentâ€™s decision to transfer sovereignty of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius, an event that will lead to the retirement of the widely used .io domain suffix in the tech and gaming industries. This geopolitical shift highlights the interconnectedness of global politics and digital infrastructure, as the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) prepares to eliminate the â€œIOâ€ country code, impacting numerous existing websites. Citing historical precedents like the fall of the Soviet Union and the breakup of Yugoslavia, Edwards cautions tech founders to consider the implications of their domain name choices, as real-world events can significantly affect the digital landscape.Read More: â€“ Cisco sells their stake in Rubrik Cisco has sold its nearly $6 million stake in cybersecurity firm Rubrik, following the companyâ€™s April IPO. Despite the sale, the two companies maintain a strategic partnership, with Rubrik joining Ciscoâ€™s SolutionsPlus program in August, making its products available on Ciscoâ€™s Global Price List.Read More: â€“ CTERAâ€™s Data Intelligence Enhances GenAI with File Data CTERA has launched its Data Intelligence offering, designed to enhance retrieval-augmented generation, or RAG, by linking cloud file services data to chosen GenAI models, providing real-time private context to improve response accuracy. CEO Oded Nagel highlighted that the service enables organizations to securely integrate their proprietary data with AI, delivering relevant insights while maintaining data privacy, through features such as semantic engines, identity-based access, and customizable virtual assistants. CTERAâ€™s solution supports both on-premises and cloud deployments, addressing challenges related to unstructured data and facilitating effective AI interactions within enterprise environments.Read More: â€“ Commvault Shiftâ€™s Cyber Resilience for the AI Era At Commvault SHIFT 2024, The Futurum Groupâ€™s Daniel Newman and Patrick Moorhead sat with CEO Sanjay Mirchandani, who discussed Commvaultâ€™s strategic pivot towards a cloud-first approach in cyber resilience. This shift involves key acquisitions, such as Appranix and Clumio, and new partnerships with AWS and Google, aimed at enhancing cloud data protection and recovery. Mirchandani also introduced the concept of â€œContinuous Business,â€ highlighting its distinction from traditional business continuity by emphasizing ongoing readiness and adaptability in a dynamic digital landscape.Read More: Gestalt IT Live Blog: As we discussed on the September 25th episode of The Rundown, Commvault announced the acquisition of Clumio. This integration, which will launch later this year, aims to accelerate Commvaultâ€™s vision of a resilient, cloud-first enterprise by leveraging Clumioâ€™s expertise in AWS to bolster cyber recovery and resilience for customers and partners.Read More: Commvault announced significant updates including full availability of its Commvault Cloud platform on AWS, support for Google Workspace protection, and a partnership with Pure Storage to help financial customers comply with the EUâ€™s Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), which comes into effect in January 2025. The new offerings, such as Cloud Rewind and the Cyber Resilience Dashboard, aim to enhance cyber resilience by enabling rapid recovery from cyber incidents while ensuring that applications and data are restored efficiently and securely across multiple cloud environments.Read More: â€“ The Weeks Ahead â€“ October 16 â€“ 17 â€“ October 23 â€“ 24 â€“ November 6 â€“ 7 Gestalt IT and  are now part of .The Gestalt IT Rundown is your look at the IT news of the week. Accidentally updated my entire system yesterday (instead of just my apps which I normally do for regular updates), which also updated to version 6. The first exp was broken, no doubt, since it defaults to , which isn't great for my GPU (the entire desktop was slow to a crawl, like it's being rendered using my CPU). Even after switching to tho, while that slowness quickly disappeared, I found that there are some widgets I rely on that are broken on Plasma 6, and even my Plank dock wasn't behaving properly (i.e. not identifying existing, open windows).

Thankfully, years ago when I first moved to full time, I had set up to create a system backup every midnight and every pre-update in case an update goes wrong (like in this case). Never had the need for it, and never bothered to test if the backups it made would work fine, until yesterday. Launched the Timeshift app on my desktop (didn't even need a safe/live environment), selected one of the recent backups, click the restore option and it was done in a second and prompted me to restart. Restarted my PC, and I was then back in my perfectly stable system on Plasma 5.27 like nothing happened <3

So please, for system backup purposes - use Timeshift! For personal file (user home directory) backups, use a based backup solution such as (which I also absolutely love). They absolutely will save your ass someday!

Update: I've added links to simple guides I've written on how I've installed and set up both Timeshift (for system backups) and Vorta (for user file backups) on my based system. Some minor things may vary on your system for the Timeshift guide, but the Vorta guide should be applicable to a tee for all Linux systems.

This week's Linux and FOSS news:LINUX NEWSGNOME 47 beta released; screen recorder supports hardware encoding, notification portal always uses GTK protocol, GDM supports gnome-remote-desktop, GNOME Web (Epiphany) gets autofill support for forms, new search field in bookmarks menu, Privacy Report, password import from CSV file; Console gets new settings; Loupe recognizes transparency correctly etc.:
KDE Gear 24.08 released; Dolphin offers new options to run operations requiring admin privileges, "Move to New Folder..." option; Konsole gets option to mark a scrollbar position to navigate long outputs more easily; Kdenlive gets UI improvements, Transform effect lets to choose clips directly from video player; Kate support new file formats; Falkon lets to set privacy settings individually on each side (Firefox extension support when?) etc.:

TIL: If your /var/ partition fills up completely with  images, you can use a different mount point for Docker data. Just change this line in /lib/systemd/system/docker.service (after stopping docker, and rsyncing all /var/lib/docker contents over)ExecStart=/usr/bin/dockerd --data-root /media/dennis/64GB_SD_EXT4/docker -H fd:// --containerd=/run/containerd/containerd.sock=/usr/bin/dockerd -H fd:// --containerd=/run/containerd/containerd.sock I ran into this issue with my  Xavier whose root disk starts with only 11GB free.

Segun xataka, NVIDIA tiene demasiado que perder, ya que en el inmenso mercado asiatico es donde tiene sus mayores ventas y obtiene la parte del leon de su utilidades... recordemos que NVIDIA fue de las primeras en reaccionar casi al instante a las medidas de prohibiciones de su gobierno desarrollando "chips unicos para China", para no perder esas ventas... tambien hizo inmensos envios de chips antes de que las prohibiciones comenzaran, sufrio de una caida en sus ventas de casi 25% una vez llegada la fecha y no parece molesta con el "supuesto contrabando que ha generado la prohibicion de chips y que posibilita el envio de ellos de manera incrustada en otros dispositivos con direccion hacia el gigante asiatico".

Al anuncio de investigacion antimonopolio que acaba de dar la agencia estatal china NVIDIA respondio que iba a cooperar en todo el proceso, pero ya esta temiendo el peor escenario. Si con las medidas de , perdio casi 1/3 de sus ventas, con esta nueva situacion y si China llega a prohibir sus chips, esto podria significar perder hasta el 60% de sus ventas. Lo que hay en juego es demasiado. Las acciones ya cayeron mas de 2,5% a los pocos minutos de anunciada la investigacion antimonopolios.

El gobierno y las asociaciones de empresarios chinos han expresado sus deseos de que "los empresarios chinos dejen de adquirir chips occidentales porque no son convenientes para los intereses locales".

I promised to post my wife's . You've seen mine, aka Infinity+3. Now check out OWLSZN-Wavy. a and I are very proud of: My wife taught me how to build a PC back in 2016. I was a console and laptop guy before her. I built my first PC based on hers at the time, and then just kept building .Unlike my line stepping ass, she values stability over theoretical performance and is old enough to have nightmares about manually overclocking things. She held on to her old build for a while but l finally acquiesced and bought new parts last year, moving from an 4790K to a 13400F . She skipped DDR4 entirely and hopped from DDR3 to DDR5. She paired that with an 3070 Ti I'm a an stan (underdog + red theming? Damn) so she prefers to stick to Intel/Nvidia to improve our risk posture.That custom cooling loop is cool AF (yeah i know) and also more expensive and troublesome than it's work but damn it's cool.She didn't want a vertical GPU (yet) or a sensor panel to monitor temps, but she WAS interested in wall mounting this beast since the case (Thermaltake P6) supports it.It was a pain finding a wall mount that would suffice, and then bolting it to the wall, but that look? *whistle noise* and it's more earthquake proof since we live near a fault line.

A Smaller VMware Explore Still Delivers News | The Gestalt IT Rundown: September 4, 2024This year, at the smallest VMware conference in many years, Broadcom made some important announcements. As weâ€™ve previously discussed, VMware Cloud Foundation 9 was detailed, along with Tanzu Platform 10, an enhanced Edge Orchestrator platform, VeloCloud Software-Defined Edge, and more. Although we miss the community coming together at VMworld every year, this smaller VMware Explore conference is very much in line with the direction taken by Broadcom since their acquisition of the company. This and more on The Rundown.  |  |  |  |  |  â€“ AnandTech Shuts its Doors After 27 years setting the standard for online tech journalism, AnandTech has published its last article. The popular tech news site, which was revered by industry insiders and tech enthusiasts, was known for impartiality, depth, and never sensationalizing the news. Although some were worried when founder and namesake Anand Lal Shimpi left for Apple, the site just continued to deliver excellent news coverage for decades. But it appears that the current owner, Future LLC (no relation to Gestalt IT parent Futurum) will cease publishing new articles on the site, thankfully keeping existing articles and forums online. The company also owns Tomâ€™s Hardware, which will continue.Read More: â€“ Rumors Fly that Intel is Changing Course The rumor mill is going wild that Intelâ€™s financial troubles are about to knock the chipmaker off of Pat Gelsingerâ€™s intended course. Weâ€™ve heard that next-generation chip fabrication isnâ€™t going well, leading to an executiveâ€™s departure. Others say Intel is looking to spin off the fab business altogether, or perhaps sell the Altera FPGA business. All of this would be a significant departure from the plans set in motion by Pat Gelsinger.Read More: â€“ Cloud providers consuming all the GPUs for AI While Dell, like other server vendors has experienced a huge growth in dedicated AI server sales there is a scarcity of Nvidia GPUs that is making delivering these servers hard. NVIDIA GPUs are being gobbled up by hyperscalers before they reach Dell and other OEMs. It may still be some time before we see the racks full of Dell PowerEdge XE9680L servers with Blackwell GPUs that Michael Dell mentioned at Dell Technologies world.Read More: â€“ Hammerspace Pulls Out a Server Hammerspace produces a respected data virtualization platform, enabling applications like AI training to access any data anywhere. One of the strengths of Hammerspace is that it is pure software, and can run just about anywhere. But now the company is announcing a partnership with reseller Arrow to ship a storage virtualization appliance based on Dell hardware.Read More: â€“ AMD Is Ready to Take On NVIDIA The latest MLCommons results just came out, and they sure make AMD look great! We have long speculated that AMDâ€™s Instinct series is competitive with Nvidiaâ€™s best AI processing GPUs, and now thereâ€™s data that says exactly that. But Nvidia still has an incredible market share lead over the competition.Read More: â€“ California Readies an AI Kill Switch The state of California is awfully worried about AI! The state legislature has overwhelmingly passed a bill requiring a so-called kill switch to all AI systems in case they get out of hand. Now itâ€™s on to Governor Gavin Newsom, who is under pressure to veto the bill. But even if he does, there appears to be support in the state legislature to override his veto and make it law.Read More: â€“ A Smaller VMware Explore Still Delivers News This year, at the smallest VMware conference in many years, Broadcom made some important announcements. As weâ€™ve previously discussed, VMware Cloud Foundation 9 was detailed, along with Tanzu Platform 10, an enhanced Edge Orchestrator platform, VeloCloud Software-Defined Edge, and more. Although we miss the community coming together at VMworld every year, this smaller VMware Explore conference is very much in line with the direction taken by Broadcom since their acquisition of the company.Read More: â€“ The Weeks Ahead â€“ September 11 â€“ 12 â€“ September 18 â€“ 19 â€“ September 24 â€“ October 2 â€“ 3 Gestalt IT and  are now part of .The Gestalt IT Rundown is your look at the IT news of the week. I've been using this Nvidia GeForce GTX 1080Ti graphics card for six years now in my gaming PC. Last year I upgraded the PC's mobo/CPU/RAM (Ryzen 7 7700X) but kept the 1080Ti in place. The GTX 1080Ti is a monster.Only available for about six months, Nvidia (over)reacted to a claim from AMD re: their upcoming GPU's performance, and released the 11GB GDDR5X 1080Ti. (AMD's claim was way over the top, it turned out.)For older, non ray-traced games (like No Man's Sky, which is the main purpose of my gaming PC), the 1080Ti notably outperforms the RTX-3060. I'm run  at 2560x1440 all settings Ultra and get 80-100fps typically. I wonder how long I will be driving this thing?

The Super Micro (SuperMicro or SUPERMICRO in some places) saga began one day when I needed a motherboard and they sold cheap PCs and motherboards. It was flaky - I think it kept resetting itself - so I went to their HQ to see if I could get it fixed or replaced.It was a very small operation. Mom & pop. The engineer there was attentive. I got my problem solved. Somewhere I have that motherboard.If I hadn't gone there then, where would they be now? Butterfly wings. You may thank me by throwing money.Today they are an Nvidia AI vendor that dropped from $70,000,000,000 in stock valuation to $20,000,000,000. WHAT???That tiny operation proves that you should never give up on your dreams!!And also that you should sell your stock sooner.

Lawsuits can be very revealing, like this one. It shows what data material is used in AI training. The fact that companies use "collected knowledge" and, for example, the well-crafted texts in a library as a basis for earning money is one of the facets of AI. The courts clarify the question of whether the authors whose texts contribute to business success must be involved in this. But what does this mean in principle for texts and graphics that are created as a product when working with an AI? Does it make a difference whether an author or graphic designer watches films and reads books - all of which are protected by various rights - takes inspiration from them and uses this inspiration to create a piece of commissioned work - or whether an AI does the same?

: "Nvidia scraped videos from Youtube and several other sources to compile training data for its AI products, internal Slack chats, emails, and documents obtained by 404 Media show. Microsoft, founded in 1975, rushing to the death of its operating system with more bloat than me after a gallon of water and salty French fries, and also making sure we never have a winter with snow, ever again. Itâ€™s a tale as old as time: Plucky young lad builds a computer in Daddyâ€™s garage, and then forty years later decides to be a supervillain, holding the entire world hostage demanding that his graphics card farms receive more power, or heâ€™ll shoot the icecaps in the face.Do you remember back when you didnâ€™t have to have an air conditioner running in March? Oh, those were the days, two years ago.I feel like this is the only thing Iâ€™m writing about. Iâ€™m not really working on my book, Iâ€™m not really putting anything new into my Second Life store. A lot of that is largely due to the fact that I have a day job, and it tires me out. Constantly. But I do happen to view social media a lot, and because of that, Iâ€™m forced to watch as corporations push the world further and further into destruction â€¦ for practically no reason.Microsoftâ€™s emissions have spiked since the beginning of the pandemic. A massive heel-turn after the world decided it was going to work toward lowering emissions. You know, so we can stop melting to death every single summer, and not die in 2040.In the article linked in the previous paragraph, Microsoft laments that the world, and they themselves, arenâ€™t meeting climate goals, and are facing â€œnew challengesâ€ as technology evolves. The problem, is that the technology theyâ€™re talking about, is AI. If youâ€™ve been reading what I write, pretty much daily, or sometimes even multiple times a day, about AI. Useless learning machines that plagiarize and generate slop that untalented people call â€œart.â€You might have seen, numerous times, over and over, as brands make posts on various social media websites and apps about image generation, or their new AI features (see: and ), and the response is always profoundly negative. Once youâ€™ve seen it so many times, you start to think, â€œHey, does anyone actually want this?â€I mean, aside from the small percentage of people who have no genuine fulfillment from any other source, and therefore resort to using theft machines to make themselves feel goodâ€”who asked for this?Why does Microsoft need to build new nuclear power plants to cool their data centers â€¦ for technology that seemingly nobody actually wants!?Itâ€™s no surprise that most brands on social media have mastered the art of utterly ignoring any and all negative feedback to their decisions that they gladly share, without shame. Aside from, I guess, maybe in regard to their ridiculous crushing press commercial.But, I wanted to pose the question to these corporations that seem to be racing to the extinction of all humanity on the backs of artists and writersâ€”stolen work and stolen words: Why? What is this revolutionizing? Did every single billionaire have an especially annoying college professor who scolded them for plagiarizing their essays, that they feel the collapse of Earthâ€™s climate is worth their revenge?â€Weâ€™re struggling to meet our climate demands amid new technologies!â€ Then stop. Itâ€™s literally that easy. We could be working toward feeding the poor and housing the homeless, and replanting forests. Instead, weâ€™re stuffing cash into so we can build data center farms for fake photos of Jesus holding dolphins with 18 fingers on each hand.The world has become a parody of itself.

If you want Arm CPU with LPDDR5X memory & high-speed interconnect to a Hopper GPU today, you are looking at NVIDIA GH200. NVIDIA has two key innovations here that really set it apart from what you can get elsewhere. First, LPDDR5X memory is soldered onto the package. Second, the NVLink-C2C is a high-bandwidth interface between the CPU and the GPU. The 72 Arm v9 cores are Arm Neoverse V2 from 2022 so not exciting.
Here's a nice look at the Grace Hopper 200 (GH200), which is Nvidia's Halfway APU chip.

So much fearmongering today about  and   use.Electricity use from data centers has traditionally grown close to linearly while the compute has grown exponentially.The projections that show exponential growth are all based on big assumptions that there really isn't a lot of evidence for.Every chip, except NVIDIA, is currently becoming massively more efficient (we are talking doubling thermal and electric efficiency expected between last gen and next gen chips). Simultaneously, 's  is dying.100% of expected new energy demand in the next decade is expected to be met by renewables, _even if_ data centers double - according to the vey same paper saying they will double by 2026.In fact, there is plenty of evidence that our entire energy sector will become an insignificant source of carbon in the next few decades.What you should be worrying about is concrete. But that's complex. It's so much simpler to say, "AI bad".

If on your :wayland: setup (with ) runs noticeably worse, check if it incorrectly autodetects something that causes it to run with .It did on my :labwc: setup and tries to use , causing it to often fail starting 4K videos:
libEGL warning: egl: failed to create dri2 screen
[vo/gpu/opengl] Suspected software renderer or indirect context.
libEGL warning: egl: failed to create dri2 screen
AO: [pipewire] 48000Hz stereo 2ch floatp
VO: [gpu] 3840x2160 yuv420p
AV: 00:00:02 / 00:02:52 (1%) A-V: -0.000 ct: -0.072
Exiting... (Quit)
X Error of failed request:  BadValue (integer parameter out of range for operation)
  Major opcode of failed request:  146 ()
  Minor opcode of failed request:  5
  Value in failed request:  0x600007
  Serial number of failed request:  39
  Current serial number in output stream:  173
You can fix it with this configuration option in ~/.config/mpv/mpv.conf:
gpu-context=waylandvk
This forces MPV to use with Wayland. You can also run mpv --gpu-context=help to see what other options you can use.

Is it normal for the monitor to change setting (refresh rate) in exactly 6 seconds?
Shouldn't it take less time? Gigabyte M32QC monitor connected DisplayPort
GeForce RTX 3060 Ti graphics
ASRock A620MHDV/M.2+ motherboard Arch Linux with Cinnamon This is a monitor with Variable refresh rate
I changed 60 Hz - 165 Hz in Cinnamon System Settings -> Screen. But I feel it when I turn on the computer, because it changes from the default 60 Hz in the bios/systemd-boot/console to my system 165 Hz. So the startup animation of the transition from the black screen to the Cinnamon desktop does not happen at all before my eyes, because the monitor is still switching the refresh rate (the resolution remains as it should be in the bios/systemd-boot/console). And when switching between TTY Ctrl+Alt+F2 etc. the same thing, it takes that long and in the background the TTY is already ready. I dream of setting 165 Hz in the bios/systemd-boot/console. But in DisplayPort, even setting the system to 60 Hz does not help, something changes anyway. For HDMI 60 Hz it is smooth, no waiting.

I have a similar, but definitely different, problem with Folding@Home and an NVIDIA GPU on Linux.The provided systemd unit includes `NoNewPrivileges=yes`, which prevents the program code from running any setuid/gid executable.You'd think this wouldn't be a problem. But, no, it seems like the NVIDIA (binary driver) CUDA libraries run `nvidia-modprobe`, which is setuid root, in order to ensure necessary modules are loaded.When running that fails you end up with an error that looks like "no CUDA support here". It does, of course, work perfectly fine if you run the actual FAH binary manually. Also then works via the systemd unit, presumably because modules are now already loaded.Workaround: `systemctl edit fah-client.service` to override `NoNewPrivileges` to `no`.I should check if explicitly loading `nvidia_uvm` (last loaded nvidia module) also works around it.

I'm just gonna compile a list of / 6 issues I'm encountering on my PC with graphics - all on the latest releases/updates.

If anyone has any input/fixes - please reply with the solution! I'll keep this list updated accordingly as I continue to use the desktop. These issues aside, Wayland on KDE Plasma 6 has been surprisingly usable likely thanks to the recent NVIDIA Explicit Sync update.

1. Constant crashes on [(Temporary) Solution: Disable hardware acceleration in Firefox]

2. Color Management (colord-kde) is showing no (display) devices available for me to apply my imported colour profiles

3. My share mount on the file manager isn't showing any thumbnails it's supposed to show (worked on ), local media files' thumbnails still load fine [Solution: Set a high enough limit for Dolphin's "Skip previews for remote files above" setting]

4. Something must have changed font-wise because my KDE Emoji Selector now shows a different set of emojis (perhaps Noto or Twemoji) than what I was using previously (Apple Emojis)

5. Fonts in general in the UI looks like garbage compared to how they looked on X11 - same fonts setting and fonts.conf config as before were used

6. Using the Task Switcher isn't laggy, but clearly slower than on X11 as I notice that the animation lags very slightly behind than my input (possibly an animation change, idk)

7. I'm being prompted to enter in my GPG passphrase instead of it reading from it by itself, and in the window prompting for the passphrase, there's no option for it to "remember" it

8. Another task switcher issue - when I'm scrolling through apps in the task switcher (by hitting Tab), those tab inputs (or any other keys I might press, really, while in the task switcher) will activate on the cursor on whatever window it was last focused on (possibly only on apps running via Xwayland) - THIS is super broken and a huge time waster for productivity [Solution: ]

9. Unlike on X11, PiP windows don't seem to remember their positioning

10. Renaming files/folders on Dolphin is just a lil broken - the text input area/space looks and aligns weirdly when you're typing and anything that used to take a single Enter key to confirm your changes now only activates on a double Enter

11. Clicking a link in an external app i.e. VS Code, Signal does open the link on the default browser - but the browser window does not take focus

12. Discover no longer offers to delete user app data files after an uninstallation of a () app

13. It's possible to adjust screen brightness from Plasma Desktop which is nice, but you cannot set different brightness levels for each individual monitor and sometimes it fucks up my monitor's colour settings and I'll have to readjust it on my monitor's OSD

14. Firefox, where tabs are located, acts really weird once there's "too many tabs" than it could fit - fine on X11
